options: Acknowledge that you can see he is feeling upset and angry.
Give him the details on how to make a complaint.
Explain firmly and clearly that his relative's situation is unfortunate but this is not your fault.
Position yourself so you are nearer to the door than he is.
Inform him that his behaviour is unacceptable.
Leave the room immediately and get help.

questions:
You are a ST3 working in General Practice. You have just broken some bad news to a family member that his loved one is dying. He becomes very upset and starts to yell blame at you while leaning over threateningly.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
This is a common scenario of an angry and aggressive patient/relative.

The correct options here are 1 (empathise), 4 (ensure own safety), and 7 (try to calm him down).

  • It is important not to further inflame the situation (option 3 and 5). He has become very upset as a reaction to receiving bad news. Speaking calmly to the person in the first instance and being empathetic is the thing to do (option 1 and 7) as long as he has not yet become physically aggressive.
  • However, he is showing signs that he might soon become physically aggressive. Therefore it would also be prudent to ensure your own safety (option 4).
  • Letting him know how to make a complaint (option 2) is a reasonable one, but here resolving the immediate situation is more crucial.
  • If the behaviour was persistent despite attempts to resolve it, or if he becomes physically aggressive by assaulting someone/destroying property, more drastic measures may have to be considered at that stage (option 6 and 8).

GMC 'Good Medical Practice':
- You must be considerate to those close to the patient and be sensitive and responsive in giving them information and support.

NHS Employers 'Violence against staff' guidance:
- NHS staff should be able to come to work without fear of violence, abuse or harassment from patients or their relatives.
- The NHS has had a zero tolerance attitude towards violence since 1999.
- The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) defines violence at work as any incident in which an employee is abused, threatened or assaulted in circumstances relating to their work. This covers the serious or persistent use of verbal abuse.

options: Advise the parents she will have to get a High Court injunction in order to stop the transfusion
Give the blood transfusion
Speak to the Watchtower Society (Jehovah's Witnesses Society) for advice
Respect parental wishes and withhold the blood transfusion
Ask the hospital lawyer to come in and decide upon the correct course of action
questions:
A 14-year-old girl is admitted to hospital following a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. She comes from a family of Jehovah's Witnesses. Her haemoglobin on admission is 6.9 g/dl. She consents to a blood transfusion but her mother refuses.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The GMC gives the following guidance:
'You should encourage young people to involve their parents in making important decisions, but you should usually abide by any decision they have the capacity to make themselves'
With respect to Jehovah's witnesses:
'You should not make assumptions about the decisions that a Jehovah's Witness patient might make about treatment with blood or blood products. You should ask for and respect their views and answer their questions honestly and to the best of your ability. You may also wish to contact the hospital liaison committees established by the Watch Tower Society (the governing body of Jehovah's Witnesses) to support Jehovah's Witnesses faced with treatment decisions involving blood. These committees can advise on current Society policy regarding the acceptability or otherwise of particular blood products. They also keep details of hospitals and doctors who are experienced in 'bloodless' medical procedures.'
A blood transfusion is clearly in the patient's best interests and in the scenario described above may potentially be life-saving. Whilst a child cannot refuse treatment they are able to provide consent. Giving the blood transfusion is therefore both clinically and ethically the right course of action.

Not giving the blood transfusion not only fails to respect the patient's wishes but also causes potential harm.

options: Contact the GMC Standards and Ethics team for advice
Write a letter to the GMC informing them of the relationship to avoid allegations of improper conduct

questions:
You are a partner at a GP practice. Whilst at a social event you meet a person with whom you begin a relationship. It becomes apparent that the person was registered at your surgery around 8 years ago and they think that they may have consulted you regarding an ankle sprain during that time. Despite this you have strong feelings for the person and want to continue the relationship.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
This scenario paints a picture of a doctor who has had minimal professional contact with a person a number of years ago.

The GMC give the following guidance on this difficult area:
'If circumstances arise in which social contact with a former patient leads to the possibility of a sexual relationship beginning, you must use your professional judgement and give careful consideration to the nature and circumstances of the relationship, taking account of the following:
  • when the professional relationship ended and how long it lasted
  • the nature of the previous professional relationship
  • whether the patient was particularly vulnerable at the time of the professional relationship, and whether they are still vulnerable
  • whether you will be caring for other members of the patient's family.

If you are not sure whether you are - or could be seen to be - abusing your professional position, it may help to discuss your situation with an impartial colleague, a defence body, medical association or (confidentially) with a member of the GMC Standards and Ethics team.'

Despite the minimal nature of the previous interaction it is important as a professional to be beyond reproach when such matters are raised. Contacting the GMC shows an open attitude and will ensure you receive appropriate guidance on your options.

options: Suggest he obtain his supply from safer sources such as local gyms.
Offer liver function tests to check that they have not damaged his liver.
Report him anonymously to the police as anabolic steroids are illegal.
Advise him to stop.
Counsel him about the risks of anabolic steroids.
Ask his family to see if they can help persuade him to stop.
Tell him that you will have no choice but to inform the authorities unless he stops injecting.
Contact his workplace to see if they have any concerns about his behaviour.
questions:
You are a FY2 working in General Practice. During a routine consultation, a 18-year-old man confides to you that he has been buying anabolic steroids over the Internet for bodybuilding purposes.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation
notes:
Anabolic steroids are a Class C drug. It is illegal to distribute but not illegal to possess for personal use.
There are many side effects and risks with taking anabolic steroids, particularly with unregulated substances purchased over the Internet.

The correct options here are 2 (offer blood tests), 4 (advise stopping), 5 (inform about risks).

  • We can immediately rule out options 3 (reporting to police), 6 (telling family), and 7 (informing authorities), as these involve breaching the patient's right to confidentiality.
  • Option 8 is also inappropriate. Even though you are not telling his workplace directly that he is using steroids, you are breaching confidentiality by indirectly letting them know that he has come to see you, and that there may be cause for concern about his behaviour.
  • Option 1 (advising a patient on the best method to illegally obtain controlled drugs) is clearly unprofessional!

Patient-doctor confidentiality can only be broken in extreme situations, and a patient using illicit drugs does not justify this, unless he is putting himself or others at risk of serious harm.

You may personally strongly disagree with the patient's decision to take recreational drugs. However this must not result in personal bias in how you treat the patient. You should offer blood tests if they are clinically appropriate.

GMC 'Good Medical Practice':
- You must not disclose personal information to a third party such as a solicitor, police officer or officer of a court without the patients express consent, unless it is required by law or can be justified in the public interest.
(Disclosing in the public interest is defined as 'to protect individuals or society from risks of serious harm, such as serious communicable diseases or serious crime'.)

- The investigations or treatment you provide or arrange must be based on the assessment you and your patient make of their needs and priorities, and on your clinical judgement about the likely effectiveness of the treatment options. You must not refuse or delay treatment because you believe that a patients actions or lifestyle have contributed to their condition.

options: Leave the patient you are clerking and immediately go and review the patient the nurse is concerned about
Complete an incident report about unnecessary bleeps before returning to clerk your patient
Explain to the nurse that you will come as soon as you can after finishing with the current patient
Request more details including basic observations

questions:
You are a junior doctor working in an acute hospital. You are aware that one of the nursing staff is well known to have a low threshold for bleeping doctors. Often he will request a review of a patient he feels is unwell, yet on review, they appear medically stable.

You are on a night-shift, clerking in a patient who has presented with an ST-elevation myocardial infarction.

The same nurse has bleeped you and is asking for a medical review of a patient who 'just doesn't look right'.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
After working in a hospital for a while you may become aware that some staff have a reputation for being very good, where as others may be on the other end of the spectrum. It is of course though important to act in a professional way at all times and always put the interests of patients first.

In this scenario you have responsibilities to two patients, the patient you are with who has been admitted with a NSTEMI and the patient you've been bleeped about who may, or may not, be unwell.

The first priority is therefore to gather more information including vital signs which could help you gauge the urgency of review. Explaining that you are with an unwell patient is helpful as is reassuring him that you will come and review the patient as soon as you can. Even if the ward patient's observations are normal it would be wrong to ignore a fellow professional who is concerned about the patient, even if he appears to have a 'reputation'.

Asking the nurse to get one of his colleagues to review the patient is obviously going to antagonise the nurse and is unlikely to result in a different outcome.

Leaving a patient who is acutely unwell is a poor option as you are potentially putting patient safety at risk.

Doing this to complete an incident form, rather than going to review another patient makes B the worst option

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:

Good communication skills are another attribute of a doctor and so it is important you apologise to the patient and inform them of the next plan of action.

A and E are similar answers however with the above in mine, A shows key communication skills and so is ranked higher.

Although this is a problem that does not need to be discussed with your consultant, it is ranked higher than C and D because it does not compromise patient care and still attempts to resolve the situation.

C and B are both very poor choices. This patient clearly needs an immediate arterial sample and leaving the sample to the next morning is a very dangerous option therefore B ranks last.

options: Remove the patient from the practice list
Set your social media settings to private
Speak to your educational supervisor about the issue
Fill out an incident form
Ignore the message
Ask your GP colleagues to see the patient in the future
Send the patient a formal warning letter
Reply to the patient, informing them that their behaviour is inappropriate
Accept the follow request
Wait until the end of your GP rotation and then accept the follow request
questions:
You are a Foundation Year 2 doctor working in General Practice. At the end of your shift, you notice that a patient that you had seen that day is requesting to follow you on social media. They have left you a message thanking you for your consultation.

Choose the THREE most appropriate actions to take in this situation.
notes:
The GMC's good medical practice guidance clearly states that doctors must maintain professional boundaries with their patients. If a patient attempts to make contact with you on social media, it is best to ignore the message (E) to avoid opening an unprofessional dialogue with the patient. Setting your social media settings to private (B) would also be appropriate to prevent other patients from searching your details and attempting to make contact online. Discussing the incident with your educational supervisor (C) is also an appropriate step, as this allows for a reflection on the incident and to talk about steps going forward.

Removing the patient from the practice list (A) is completely inappropriate - they may not have understood that doctors cannot befriend patients on social media. Removal from the practice register usually follows a serious event, such as threats or actions of verbal or physical violence and usually follows a process of issuing verbal and written warnings - it is completely unwarranted here. Asking your GP colleagues to see the patient in the future (F) is premature at this stage and may damage the existing doctor-patient relationship. However, if repeated attempts to contact you on social media are made, then this request may be necessary. Sending the patient a formal warning letter (G) is premature and unwarranted here. Responding to the friend request and telling the patient that their behaviour is inappropriate (H) risks damaging the rapport that you have built with your patient and is unprofessional behaviour. Filling out an clinical incident form (D) is not an immediate step that needs to be taken for a friend request on social media. However, the least appropriate options would be to accept the friend request either immediately (I) or at the end of the rotation (J).

The GMC's good medical practice guidance clearly states that doctors must maintain professional boundaries with their patients. If a patient attempts to make contact with you on social media, it is best to ignore the message (E) to avoid opening an unprofessional dialogue with the patient. Setting your social media settings to private (B) would also be appropriate to prevent other patients from searching your details and attempting to make contact online. Discussing the incident with your educational supervisor (C) is also an appropriate step, as this allows for a reflection on the incident and to talk about steps going forward.

Removing the patient from the practice list (A) is completely inappropriate - they may not have understood that doctors cannot befriend patients on social media. Removal from the practice register usually follows a serious event, such as threats or actions of verbal or physical violence and usually follows a process of issuing verbal and written warnings - it is completely unwarranted here. Asking your GP colleagues to see the patient in the future (F) is premature at this stage and may damage the existing doctor-patient relationship. However, if repeated attempts to contact you on social media are made, then this request may be necessary. Sending the patient a formal warning letter (G) is premature and unwarranted here. Responding to the friend request and telling the patient that their behaviour is inappropriate (H) risks damaging the rapport that you have built with your patient and is unprofessional behaviour. Filling out an clinical incident form (D) is not an immediate step that needs to be taken for a friend request on social media. However, the least appropriate options would be to accept the friend request either immediately (I) or at the end of the rotation (J).
title: GMC: social media
body:
The GMC has produced detailed guidance on the use of social media.

One of the key passages discusses anonymity online:


17. If you identify yourself as a doctor in publicly accessible social media, you should also identify yourself by name. Any material written by authors who represent themselves as doctors is likely to be taken on trust and may reasonably be taken to represent the views of the profession more widely.§

18. You should also be aware that content uploaded anonymously can, in many cases, be traced back to its point of origin.

Please see the link for more details.

options: Confirm she is stable but make no further comment
Ignore the reporters
Offer the information in exchange for a donation to the hospital
Use the opportunity to comment on the dangers of an excessive alcohol intake
Advise the reporter to speak to your consultant
questions:
You are a ST1 in the Emergency Department. A famous pop singer ('Danni Domino') has been admitted under your consultant with abdominal pain. Admission bloods show a raised amylase and pancreatitis is suspected. On leaving the hospital a local newspaper reporter stops you and asks you how Danni is doing.

Rank in order the following actions in response to this situation
(1 = Most appropriate; 5 = Least appropriate)
notes:
The GMC make it very clear:
'Patients have a right to expect that information about them will be held in confidence by their doctors. You must treat information about patients as confidential, including after a patient has died.'

There are no circumstances where you should speak to reporters in such a situation. Advising the reporter to speak to your consultant acknowledges that Danni is in the hospital. Using the opportunity to comment on the dangers of an excessive alcohol intake is completely inappropriate as it gives information about the patient's medical history.

Offering to sell patient information is clearly the worst option.
